response.answer_text: Apple, Microsoft, Razer, and Dell are currently leading the way in the laptop race. All of these brands offer a variety of options with different price ranges. Apple’s MacBook lineup These don’t need an introduction. The MacBook Air is a beloved and popular laptop model. The recent update of the model includes Apple’s Retina display and a fingerprint sensor. Starting from $1099 these are a great option for those people that want portability but who aren’t planning to do graphics-heavy tasks with it. MacBook Pro models are designed to handle the latter.  With both 13-inch and 16-inch models available, the MacBook Pro lineup is an amazing option for professionals. That is professionals who receive “professional” salaries because these laptops cost real money and they start at around $2399 for the 16-inch versions.  Everything about the MacBooks is amazing. The Retina displays are great, the trackpads are one-of-a-kind in the industry, and the metal casing of the MacBook is the gold standard. Dell’s XPS lineup Dell XPS laptops are one of the best Windows laptops right now. The most prominent feature of this lineup is the bezel-less display. No other laptop has that minimal bezels around the screen.  The Dell XPS laptops also stand up with their lightweight build. These are one of the most portable Windows laptops currently available. These come in both 13-inch and 15-inch screen sizes. Prices start at around $880. Microsoft Surface lineup The Surface lineup has a wide variety of choices available. Both traditional laptops and hybrid tablet/laptop are available under this brand. Surface Laptop 3 is one of the highest-quality Windows laptops available. These are beautiful looking laptops that have all the essentials that you may need for work. Although they aren’t great for graphics-heavy work.  Surface Book 2 is a hybrid. Its screen detaches and can be used as a tablet. You can use a stylus with it which makes it great for creative tasks. Microsoft Surface Laptop starts at $999, while Surface Book 2 starts at around $1149. Razer’s Blade lineup Razer is known to produce powerful laptops in small packages. The Razer Stealth is the lightest gaming laptop lineup. These come in different screen size options from 13.3- to 17-inch versions.  Razer too shines with high quality builds and beautiful designs. It has both a fingerprint sensor and supports Windows Hello face recognition technology. You can play the latest game titles on this model and also do graphics-heavy tasks. Razer Stealth starts at around $1399.

I think the best will continue to be a toss-up between the ROG Strix and the MSI Stealth lineup. ASUS and MSI have gotten it right with 144Hz IPS displays, amazing keyboards, and fantastic cooling solutions. I personally love the idea of cramming a 17″ high refresh rate screen into a 15″ laptop.  I think the MSI GS75 Stealth is a work of art. Other manufacturers are getting the hint and following these excellent design trends, so 2020 looks to be a very good year for mobile devices!  EDIT: I love this discussion. It shows truly how far we are from really engineering the “perfect” gaming laptop. The inclusion of so many ports on the left side of the ROG GL704 means that cooling was sacrificed, putting it in the same boat as the i9 MacBook pro. Another model I thought to mention was the Acer Predator Triton 500 (reviewed last week by Dave Lee) because of its rock solid design and good cooling. Acer gets an “A” for effort, but the overall design is extremely plain for an $1800 gaming device despite its appealing “boxy” shape—and the interior design makes upgrading a very unappealing prospect. I know they (and all the OEM’s) will make great strides over the next several months to come up with better layouts for 2020.

A laptop is composed of different parts and each part is responsible for a different type of function. It depends upon your needs which laptop is best for you. So, let's discuss the most important parts of it and check which are suitable for you. 1. Processors It is the most important part and serves the main function of a laptop. It is responsible for the speed of the laptop to perform a task like starting time of a program or windows. So, if you want a laptop with good speed or you want to run heavy programs or games, you have to buy a laptop of the high-speed processor. If you want a high-level gaming processor, it should be minimum 4-Cores (Quad-Core) and clock speed should be more than 3.0 GHz and it should have more than 4MB cache. 2. Rams Ram also has great effect on the performance of a laptop. Ram decides how many programs you can run on a computer at a time. Ram actually loads what you are interacting or working with. So, for high performance or to run heavy programs Ram should be high. Your Ram should be 4GB minimum and if you want more heavy gaming than it should be more than 8GB. 3. Graphic Cards You don’t actually need a graphic card if you are a simple worker and use laptops for simple and average programs. If you want to play heavy games or programs which use heavy graphics then you can think of embedding graphics card. There are two most common brands in the market i.e. AMD and Nvidia. Both are working good and excellent reviews. Starting from 1GB, there are many versions 2GB, 4GB, 8GB, depending upon the requirements of your games or programs. 4. Hard Disk Hard disks are only for storing data. There are two types of hard disks HDD and SSD. HDD is cheap but old technology; therefore, their speed is slow as compared to SSD which are almost 10 times faster but expensive. Hard disk’s speed is measured by the rate of transferring data into or out of the hard drives.

What is your definition of best. Best for your use? Best for performance? Best performance versus cost? Best manufacturer? There is no definitive answer. Sure you received a lot of suggestions from respondents, based on their personal or perceived preferences, but there is no clear choice. Shop for the hardware specs that you need for your expected use. Chose the laptop that fits your needs and price range. Then research that laptop to make a decision. Check user and review sites reviews, google for issues with the model that you want, if you see a pattern of the same issue being reported by many reviewers or from google searches, look for something else. Do not expect any one manufacturer to have all good or all bad laptops. They all have their great models and they all have their junk. You have to do your homework. Don’t rely on anyone to know what your needs are.
